reasoning: The critique targets the paper’s use of digital-being rights as an illustrative dimension of “eutopian fragility,” arguing the analysis misses an adversarial/mechanism-design dynamic (strategic mass-production of purported moral patients) that changes what the real crux is. This is only moderately central: digital minds are one of many examples supporting fragility, and the paper’s more technical case for “fussiness” (bounded/unbounded value functions, scaling, aggregation of goods/bads) would largely stand even if the digital-minds subsection were revised. The critique’s argument is plausible and conceptually important, but it remains somewhat gestural: it doesn’t show that Forethought’s existing point is wrong so much as incomplete, and it doesn’t clearly demonstrate that the missing adversarial dynamic undermines (rather than reinforces) ‘no easy eutopia’—it may actually add another reason eutopia is hard. Relevance is high because digital minds’ moral status and governance are explicitly Tier 3 and the critique highlights a concrete cross-over between moral uncertainty and adversarial incentives/security. Overall, it’s a useful agenda-relevant refinement, but it doesn’t substantially refute the core thesis.
title: "Digital Personhood as an Adversarial Attack Surface"
